transcript:
For this project, I built an AI-powered variance explainer.
The goal is to take a basic budget versus actual table and automatically turn it into a clear, management-ready narrative using AI.

Instead of manually writing variance explanations every month, this tool generates a first draft explanation that finance teams or managers can actually use.

Problem Definition (DRIVER – D)

The problem I'm solving is that variance analysis is repetitive and time-consuming.

Finance teams spend a lot of time:

calculating variances,

sorting through what matters,

and then writing explanations that often follow the same structure every month.

The numbers are easy to calculate, but explaining why something happened and what it means takes time. That's where AI fits well.

Approach and Tools (DRIVER – R)

My approach was to separate responsibilities:

Python and pandas handle all numeric logic

Streamlit handles the interactive user interface

An AI language model handles explanation and narrative

The AI never calculates numbers.
It only explains results that were already calculated correctly in code.

That separation is intentional so the output stays accurate.

Walkthrough: How the Tool Works (DRIVER – I)

I'll walk through the app.

At the top, the app explains what it does and how to use it.

First, the user uploads a CSV or Excel file that contains:

one label column, like Account or Department,

a Budget column,

and an Actual column.

After uploading the file, the user selects:

which column is the label,

which column represents Budget,

and which column represents Actual.

The app then calculates:

variance value as Actual minus Budget,

variance percent as that difference divided by Budget.

It sorts the table by absolute variance percent, so the biggest drivers appear first.

Variance Results and Validation

Before involving AI, the app clearly shows:

the full variance table,

and the top positive and negative drivers calculated mathematically.

Positive and negative variances are explicitly separated in Python, not by the AI.
This prevents the model from mislabeling results.

If the data is invalid, for example if there are not enough numeric columns, the app stops and shows a clear error message.

Trend Analysis (Loop 3 Enhancement)

If the dataset includes a time or period column, such as Month or Quarter, the app adds trend analysis.

It:

groups Budget and Actual by period,

recalculates variance by period,

and displays a line chart showing how Budget and Actual change over time.

This gives additional context beyond a single snapshot and allows the AI to comment on trends, not just one-time variances.

AI Explanation Output

Once the calculations are complete, the user clicks Generate AI variance explanation.

The AI receives:

the top positive variances,

the top negative variances,

and optionally a trend table if available.

The AI is instructed to output explanations in this order:

Explanation of variance

Positive variances

Negative variances

CFO summary

All explanations are written in bullet points for clarity.

The AI does not invent numbers or move items between categories.
It only explains what the system already calculated.

Value and Validation (DRIVER – V)

This tool solves a real problem because:

it reduces time spent writing repetitive explanations,

it produces consistent, structured narratives,

and it's usable by non-technical users.

I tested it with multiple datasets, including multi-period data, and verified that the explanations always match the calculated results.

Extensions and Scalability (DRIVER – E)

There are several ways this could scale:

adding forecast versus actual comparisons,

tracking cumulative variances over time,

or exporting the AI explanation directly into a report or slide deck.

The structure already supports those extensions.

Reflection and Learning (DRIVER – R)

The hardest parts of this project were:

learning how Streamlit reruns scripts on every interaction,

managing errors and edge cases cleanly,

and prompt design to keep the AI grounded in the data.

The biggest takeaway is that AI is most effective when it's constrained.
Let code handle logic and math, and let AI handle interpretation.

Closing

Overall, this project demonstrates that I can:

build a working, interactive tool,

integrate AI responsibly,
and solve a real finance problem in a practical way.
